channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: A.N.C. Suffers Worst Election Setback Since End of Apartheid
item.description: In nationwide municipal elections, South Africans rebuked the African National Congress, handing it less than half the collective vote for the first time in its history.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Voters on Monday in Alexandra township in South Africa. Councilors and mayors were on the ballot, but voters used the opportunity to vent their grievances over national issues.

item.title: Trieste, Center of Italy’s Anti-Vaccine Protests, Is Now a Covid Hot Spot
item.description: After leading the resistance to the government’s new health pass, the northeastern port city of Trieste is home to a worrying spike in cases.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Police officers sprayed water jets at protesters blocking a gate in the port of Trieste last month during a demonstration against the country’s new health pass.

item.title: Israel Passes State Budget
item.description: The vote raised hopes that the country might be headed for a period of more political stability after the chaos of four elections in quick succession.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Legislators narrowly passed the state budget in Israel’s Parliament in Jerusalem, removing an imminent threat to the survival of the government.

item.title: Cleo Smith Abduction: Australian Man Is Charged After 18-Day Search
item.description: The legal action came as the Australian authorities continued to address questions about how the police had been able to find Cleo Smith, who vanished from a remote campsite.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Richard Wainwright/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers outside the house in Carnarvon, Australia, where Cleo Smith, 4, was rescued.

item.title: Iran Seizes an Oil Tanker, but Whose Tanker Is Disputed
item.description: U.S. and Iranian officials gave conflicting accounts of a ship that was seized last month. Some reports said it was the same tanker the United States had seized last year. The Pentagon denied that.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Planet Labs Inc., via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite photograph shows the Vietnamese-flagged oil tanker Southys, the red vessel at the far bottom right, on Saturday, off the coast of Bandar Abbas, Iran.

item.title: ISIS Poses a Growing Threat to New Taliban Government in Afghanistan
item.description: The Taliban takeover was supposed to bring an end to war, the new government promised. But a growing insurgency is upending security and raising alarms for the international community.
item.dc:creator: Victor J. Blue, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban NDS police patrol the center of the city in Jalalabad, last month.

item.title: Video Showed Child in Area Minutes Before Kabul Drone Strike
item.description: An investigation of the Aug. 29 airstrike, which mistakenly killed 10 civilians, including seven children, did not recommend any disciplinary action.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene of an airstrike in Kabul, Afghanistan, in August that the military has acknowledged mistakenly killed 10 civilians, including seven children.

item.title: U.S. Blacklists Israeli Firm NSO Group Over Spyware
item.description: The ban is the strongest step an American president has taken to curb abuses in the global market for spyware.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth, Ana Swanson and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: An office of the NSO Group in Sapir, Israel. The company makes surveillance software which can be remotely implanted in smartphones.

item.title: Ethiopia’s Leader Vows to ‘Bury This Enemy,’ Even as Rebels Advance
item.description: A United Nations report, released as Tigrayan rebels near the capital, documents atrocities on all sides in a year-old civil war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia last month during his inauguration ceremony in Addis Ababa. He was sworn in for a second five-year term.

item.title: From BTS to ‘Squid Game’: How South Korea Became a Cultural Juggernaut
item.description: The country was once largely known for cars and smartphones, but a global audience has become mesmerized by its entertainment, and creators say success didn’t happen overnight.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: The K-Pop band Blackpink, which has conquered markets in Asia and beyond.

item.title: Weapons Tracing Study Implicates Russia in Ukraine Conflict
item.description: One of the most comprehensive studies to date of weaponry in the war in Ukraine shows a panoply of Russian-supplied arms that has helped fuel the war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the pro-Russian Vostok Battalion practicing in Donetsk in 2014.

item.title: Torn From Parents in the Belgian Congo, Women Seek Reparations
item.description: Belgium has apologized for the kidnapping and deportation of thousands of mixed-race children under its colonial rule. Survivors say that reparations should be the next step.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Noelle Verbeeken, Lea Tavares Mujinga and Simone Ngalula, three of the five women who are suing the Belgian state for crimes against humanity.

item.title: China's Peng Shuai Makes #MeToo Claim Against Zhang Gaoli
item.description: Peng Shuai’s accusation against Zhang Gaoli takes the country’s budding #MeToo movement to the top echelons of the Communist Party for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: The Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai at the Australian Open in Melbourne, Australia, in January 2020.

item.title: Why Is Ethiopia at War in the Tigray Region?
item.description: The civil war has shifted dramatically since Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed began a military campaign in the Tigray region a year ago. With Tigrayan fighters advancing toward the capital, Ethiopia is at risk of collapse.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A parade for the 45th anniversary of the establishment of the Tigray People’s Liberation Front, in Mekelle, in February 2020.

item.title: NASA’s Latest Breakthrough: ‘Best Space Tacos Yet’
item.description: For the first time, astronauts on the International Space Station cultivated chiles, adding some zing to their tacos.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Mark Vande Hei, a NASA astronaut, helped cultivate chiles on the International Space Station last month.

item.title: W.H.O. Official: 'Europe Is Back at Epicenter of the Pandemic'
item.description: The World Health Organization said Europe was responsible for nearly three-fifths of the world’s recent coronavirus cases, and that deaths in the region were surging.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Coronavirus cases and deaths are surging in Europe, and hospitals are filling with Covid-19 patients, like this one in an intensive care unit in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Effort to Reframe Climate Change as a Health Crisis Gains Steam
item.description: Research has increasingly shown that warming is taking a deadly toll on human health. At the global climate summit in Glasgow, the issue has gained new prominence.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ambulances left the American Medical Response in Portland, Ore., in July during a record-breaking heatwave.

item.title: A New 10-Year Plan for the Cosmos
item.description: On astronomers’ wish list for the next decade: two giant telescopes and a space telescope to search for life and habitable worlds beyond Earth.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.category: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine

item.title: Facing a New Surge, Germany Sets a Daily Virus Case Record
item.description: The country registered 33,949 new coronavirus cases over a 24-hour period on Wednesday, surpassing a high set in December of last year.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A line for vaccinations in Berlin on Wednesday. Only 67 percent of Germans are fully inoculated, a rate that lags behind that of several European neighbors.

item.title: India's Diwali Celebrations Draw Large Crowds Despite Covid Concerns
item.description: More than 680,000 people have traveled across the country as health experts cautioned that large-scale gatherings might fuel a wave of infections.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Along the Sarayu River in Ayodhya, India, on Wednesday.

item.title: What's Behind Democrats' Struggle With Working-Class Voters
item.description: Democrats’ struggles with working-class voters seem to be getting worse.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Carlos Bernate for The New York Times
item.media:description: Youngkin supporters at a campaign event.

item.title: Hawaii Eases Covid Restrictions and Reopens for Tourists
item.description: The state is eager for its vacation industry to rebound after a devastating 2020 season.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Shopping in Waikiki, a neighborhood of Honolulu, in August.

item.title: The Art and Ritual of Rangoli
item.description: Making ornate floor art can be a celebratory act for festivals like Diwali and a meditative practice.
item.dc:creator: Anna P. Kambhampaty
item.media:description: Jugnu Verma making rangoli outside her home in South Carolina.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A deal to end the use of coal.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A coal-fired power plant in Bogatynia, Poland.

item.title: Back in Chicago, Woman Is Charged in Killing of Mother on Indonesian Vacation
item.description: Heather L. Mack, 26, had already served more than six years in prison in Indonesia for the 2014 killing of her mother, whose body was found in a suitcase at a Bali resort.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Heather L. Mack was escorted by Indonesian immigration officials after she was released from prison in Bali on Friday.

item.title: 18 Countries to Phase Out Coal, According to Leaked Document
item.description: The countries, banks and other organizations that make up a new coalition will commit to ending all investment in new coal power generation domestically and internationally.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal mine in Bogatynia, Poland. According to a document seen by The New York Times, Polish officials have agreed to a plan to phase out coal.

item.title: With scant vaccine supplies, the W.H.O. presses Latin America and the Caribbean to hold off on boosters.
item.description: Sufficient shipments of doses have been slow to reach many countries in the region and economic inequalities are complicating matters.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Administering a dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine in Managua, Nicaragua, in September.

item.title: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles tests positive for the virus.
item.description: Mr. Garcetti’s office said the mayor, who is in Scotland for a conference on climate change, was feeling good and had been fully vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gregory
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles in May.

item.title: Scotland's Nicola Sturgeon: 'We're Running out of Time."
item.description: The leader of the nation hosting COP26 said she hoped that a century from now, people will look back and “describe Glasgow as the place which really took the correct fork in the road for our planet.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jeff J Mitchell
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, leader of the Scottish government, at the opening of the New York Times Climate Hub on Wednesday in Glasgow.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Election losses leave U.S. Democrats reeling.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Republican candidate for governor in Virginia, Glenn Youngkin, after winning the race.

item.title: Damon Galgut Wins Booker Prize for ‘The Promise’
item.description: The novelist, shortlisted for two of his previous books, received one of the world’s most prestigious literary awards for his cutting depiction of a white family in post-apartheid South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:description: Damon Galgut in London last month. He is this year’s Booker Prize winner for his novel “The Promise.”

item.title: Greece Tightens Covid Restrictions on the Unvaccinated
item.description: The restrictions start Saturday and target unvaccinated people, said the country’s health minister, Thanos Plevris.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Outside the Greek Parliament, in Athens, on Wednesday, health workers and demonstrators protest mandatory Covid-19 vaccines.

item.title: European Steel Plan Shows Biden’s Bid to Merge Climate and Trade Policy
item.description: A potential agreement on steel trade provides the clearest look yet at how the Biden administration plans to implement a trade policy that is both protectionist and progressive
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A welder working on a steel pipe at a factory in Santa Maria degli Angeli, Italy. The Biden administration plans to negotiate a trade arrangement with the European Union that would encourage the production of steel made with fewer carbon emissions.

item.title: At COP26, Gore Says Satellite Emissions Monitoring Helps Climate-Change Fight
item.description: Real-time checks on where greenhouse gases are being produced may prove a powerful weapon in the fight to cool the earth.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Craig Gibson For The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Al Gore, speaking at the Climate Hub, a New York Times event series taking place alongside the COP26 Climate Conference in Glasgow, Scotland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Covaxin, Vaccine Developed in India, Gets W.H.O. Clearance
item.description: The vaccine is the eighth coronavirus vaccine to receive the global health body’s green light.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: A health worker administered a dose of the Covaxin coronavirus vaccine at a health center in Garia, India, last month.

item.title: China Could Have 1,000 Nuclear Warheads by 2030, Pentagon Says
item.description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called Beijing the “No. 1” nation-state military challenger to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Chinese military vehicles carrying DF-41 ballistic missiles roll during a parade in Beijing in 2019 to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China.

item.title: Sunao Tsuboi, 96, Dies; Hiroshima Victim Who Lived to Tell His Story
item.description: After suffering through the agony of the attack and its aftermath, he devoted himself to spreading the message that nuclear weapons should be abolished.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Sunao Tsuboi in 2016. A survivor of the bombing of Hiroshima, he went on to devote himself to the cause of nuclear disarmament.

item.title: COP26 Summit Attendees Frustrated With Long Lines and Access
item.description: One veteran of the annual gathering described it as the “poorest planed” to date. A young American activist called it a “hellscape.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delegates arriving at the COP26 climate conference in Glasgow this week.

item.title: Protesters March Against ‘Greenwashing' at COP26
item.description: As the focus of the Glasgow summit turns to funding, protesters call for greater accountability for companies’ climate promises.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists took part in a ‘Greenwash’ march through central Glasgow, Scotland, Wednesday.

item.title: As deadlines loom, the U.S. military grants few vaccine exemptions.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:description: Roughly 97 percent of U.S. active-duty service members have received at least one dose of the vaccine.

item.title: What Did Scott Morrison, Australia's Leader, Accomplish at COP26?
item.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison did not announce any firm plans to move away from the country’s deep investment in fossil fuel production.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor and Damien Cave
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Collinsville coal mine seen from above, in Queensland, Australia.

item.title: U.S. to Provide $500 Million for Green Bonds, Yellen Says
item.description: Ms. Yellen said wealthy countries had pledged billions of dollars to tackle climate change, but the real cost is in the trillions.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Eshe Nelson
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen at the COP26 in Glasgow.

item.title: Duterte vows to punish Philippine officials for slow vaccine delivery.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:credit: Aaron Favila/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Manila last month. The country has fully inoculated only about a third of the eligible population.

item.title: Virginia Goes Red
item.description: Republicans had a good election night.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glenn Youngkin after defeating Terry McAuliffe in Virginia.

item.title: New $10.5 Billion Fund Aims to Spur Green Energy in Poor Countries
item.description: Its backers say it will jump-start investments in clean energy that would not otherwise draw private investors.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet
item.media:description: A solar park in the Indian state of Karnataka.

item.title: Financial Industry, With $130 Trillion, to Pursue Climate Goals
item.description: The pledge would transform the international financial system, but critics say it falls short on fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Eshe Nelson
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Mark Carney, the former head of the Bank of England, is leading the the United Nations Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero.

item.title: Governments Must Invest in Jobs in Green Economy, Ban Ki-moon Says.
item.description: His comments come amid rising concern that transitioning to a greener economy could provoke a backlash if the cost falls to low- and middle-income people.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, the former U.N. secretary general, in September.

item.title: South Africa to Get $8.5 billion to Shift From Coal to Renewables
item.description: Developing nations have long said they need aid from wealthy countries to shift to renewable energy. South Africa may show how that would work in practice.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The coal-fired Kusile Power Station in Mpumalanga Province, South Africa, in 2019.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Developments at the COP26 climate summit.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, President of Congo Felix Tshisekedi and President Biden before speaking at the “action on forests and land-use” event at COP26 in Glasgow, Scotland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Cleo Smith, 4, Is Found 18 Days After She Vanishes in Australia
item.description: Cleo Smith disappeared one night while camping with her family in a remote area of Australia. She was found “alive and well” in a locked house, and a man was detained.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Cleo Smith’s mother, Ellie Smith, with Cleo’s stepfather, Jake Gliddon. Cleo was found “alive and well” in a locked house 18 days after her disappearance.

item.title: With Methane and Forest Deals, Climate Summit Offers Hope After Gloomy Start
item.description: Agreements to reduce methane gas emissions and protect the world’s forests were reached Tuesday at the U.N.-sponsored meeting, as President Biden chided the leaders of Russia and China for not showing up.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Katie Rogers and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Biden at a news conference in Glasgow on Tuesday. He told reporters the meeting had re-established the United States as a leader in fighting climate change.

item.title: Building in Nigeria Had ‘Abnormalities’ Before Collapse
item.description: At least 20 people were killed when the high-rise in an upscale neighborhood in the commercial capital of Lagos crumbled on Monday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Ben Ezeamalu and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Rubble of the 21-story building that collapsed in Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Biden knocks China and Russia.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: “By showing up, we’ve had a profound impact,” President Biden said at the climate summit in Glasgow.

item.title: Palestinian Families Reject Deal in Area That Helped Set Off Gaza Conflict
item.description: The threatened evictions of Palestinian residents of the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood of East Jerusalem led to a war in Gaza last May.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: The Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood in East Jerusalem, where a court has threatened to evict several Palestinian families.

item.title: U.S.-Russia Engagement Deepens as C.I.A. Head Travels to Moscow
item.description: It was at least the fourth trip to Moscow since July by a senior American official as the two sides seek to stabilize a volatile relationship.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, in February. His trip to Moscow was at least the fourth such trip since July by a senior American official.

item.title: Ethiopia Declares State of Emergency as Rebels Advance Toward Capital
item.description: In a milestone in the yearlong conflict, the government called on civilians to arm themselves and defend Addis Ababa after Tigrayan forces captured two towns nearby.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tigrayan fighters have been battling the army of the central government in Ethiopia for year. They are pictured here in June in Mekelle, capital of the Tigray region.

item.title: Once a Climate Leader, Brazil Falls Short in Glasgow
item.description: The country’s proposals show a desire to burnish its image, but President Jair Bolsonaro’s record and his absence from the summit cast doubt on its commitment to reversing course.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian workers fighting a fire that encroached into the Amazon forest in 2019. President Jair Bolsonaro has been condemned at home and abroad over the widespread neglect of environmental regulations.

item.title: Facebook Plans to Shut Down Its Facial Recognition System
item.description: Saying it wants “to find the right balance” with the technology, the social network will delete the face scan data of more than one billion users.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Facebook is shuttering a feature, introduced in December 2010, that automatically identified people who appeared in users’ digital photo albums.

item.title: Karine Elharrar, Israel's Energy Minister, Couldn't Attend COP26 Events in Her Wheelchair
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Karine Elharrar, the Israeli minister of energy, before a meeting with Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Tuesday. Mr. Johnson apologized for the lack of wheelchair access.
